Selected Answer: B
I did not find any relevant information about this. As I understand what telemetry does (it automatically collects, transmits and measures data from remote sources, using sensors and other devices, and it transmits the data back to a central location) per-interfaces stats could a good candidate.

Selected Answer: B
What an interesting question indeed lol....

Would have to vote B for this one though. Reason being is because per-interface stats typically requires network telemetry to be enabled so that detailed information about traffic flows, interface utilization, errors, and other performance metrics can be gathered from network devices. 

Also, from the link pasted by jienBoq: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/cloud-systems-management/network-automation-and-management/dna-center/2-2-2/user_guide/b_cisco_dna_center_ug_2_2_2/b_cisco_dna_center_ug_2_2_2_chapter_01010.pdf

" The NetFlow configuration on the device INTERFACES is completed ONLY when you enable application telemetry on the device."

Selected Answer: D
The only feature in this selection that requires a functioning telemetry infrastructure is "SNMP trap notification".
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/cloud-systems-management/network-automation-and-management/dna-center/2-2-2/user_guide/b_cisco_dna_center_ug_2_2_2/b_cisco_dna_center_ug_2_2_2_chapter_01010.pdf

Selected Answer: A
https://device.report/manual/9961645
 Configure a Span of L2 Traffic

 On the organization's network, configure a Layer 2 (L2) aggregation switch, or similar, to span a stream of the L2 traffic to the Cisco DNA Traffic Telemetry Appliance. This must be a distribution layer switch (based on a three-layer networking model of access layer, distribution layer, core layer) in order to include traffic and devices from all segments of the access layer.
 The Cisco DNA Traffic Telemetry Appliance uses the span for traffic analysis and device discovery.

Tricky. I no docs here. But going with per int stats. B.

Telemetry isn't based off logs. Its real time statistics from whats happening on the network. This is gathered by the statistics on the networking device.

Selected Answer: B
B. per-interface stats

comments.content: what is central syslog system ? remote syslog server collects syslog messages, what does it have to do with telemetry...

Initially I would go for B, but after reviewing documentation and checking all the other options, I must agree.
SNMP trap notification doesn't need telemetry to be enabled, neither neighbor discovery, but a central syslog system won't work without telemetry.
Interface stats are there, they are always working, it's just that they won't be sent anywhere without telemetry, but that's not the question.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
SHA corresponds to hash which in the case of ISAKMP/IPSec policies will always relate to integrity. "Specifies the hash algorithm used to ensure data integrity. It ensures that a packet comes from where it says it comes from, and that it has not been modified in transit."

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/asa/asa72/configuration/guide/conf_gd/ike.html

The same concept is used to verify file integrity e.g. firmware files. Good to check the firmware SHA/MD5 checksums, prior to applying/rebooting, so you don't end up bricking your device.

questions.question_text: What is provided by the Secure Hash Algorithm in a VPN?

choices.D: No traffic will be allowed through to the DMZ_inside zone unless it's already trusted.
choices.B: All traffic from any zone will be allowed to the DMZ_inside zone only after inspection.
choices.A: No traffic will be allowed through to the DMZ_inside zone regardless of if it’s trusted or not.
choices.C: All traffic from any zone to the DMZ_inside zone will be permitted with no further inspection.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Trust - allow without inspection.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Trust: Sends traffic straight to the egress interface, without any extra inspections. Identity policies and rate limiting still apply

Selected Answer: C
C, there is no complication here. The trust action allows traffic with no inspection
I agree with C

Selected Answer: C
It is C. no brainer there

Selected Answer: D
D sounds right to me.

comments.content: Why does that sound right to you? Obviously the "Action" is "Trust" so traffic is permitted without inspecting it.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. When configuring this access control rule in Cisco FMC, what happens with the traffic destined to the DMZ_inside zone once the configuration is deployed?
A company identified a phishing vulnerability during a pentest. What are two ways the company can protect employees from the attack? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
ESA - Email
Umbrella - DNS/URL Block..
B&C is correct

B. using Cisco Umbrella
C. using Cisco ESA

Selected Answer: BC
B & C is correct:

The following are the benefits of deploying Cisco Advanced Phishing Protection on the Cisco Email Security Gateway (ESA):
Prevents the following:

Attacks that use compromised accounts and social engineering.
Phishing, ransomware, zero-day attacks and spoofing.
BEC with no malicious payload or URL.

Cisco Umbrella protects users from accessing malicious domains by proactively analyzing and blocking unsafe destinations – before a connection is ever made. Thus it can protect from phishing attacks by blocking suspicious domains when users click on the given links that an attacker sent.

Selected Answer: BC
The answer is B & C
The following are the benefits of deploying Cisco Advanced Phishing Protection on the Cisco Email Security Gateway (ESA):

Prevents the following:
+ Attacks that use compromised accounts and social engineering.
+ Phishing, ransomware, zero-day attacks and spoofing.
+ BEC with no malicious payload or URL.

Reference: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/esa/esa13-5/user_guide/b_ESA_Admin_Guide_13-5/m_advanced_phishing_protection.html

Cisco Umbrella protects users from accessing malicious domains by proactively analyzing and blocking unsafe destinations – before a connection is ever made. Thus it can protect from phishing attacks by blocking suspicious domains when users click on the given links that an attacker sent.

BE: 
Cisco Email Security Appliance (ESA) is an email security solution that provides protection against spam, phishing, malware, and other email-borne threats. While it can be an effective tool for preventing employees from receiving phishing emails, it does not provide the same level of protection as Umbrella and FTD. Umbrella is a cloud-based security service that provides protection against phishing and other types of internet-based threats by blocking access to known malicious domains and IP addresses, and FTD is a next-generation firewall that integrates advanced threat protection capabilities, such as intrusion prevention (IPS), advanced malware protection (AMP), and URL filtering. These two solutions focus on the network level, providing the first line of defense and blocking the phishing website before it reaches the employees. While ESA focus on the email level, it can detect and block malicious emails, but it doesn't protect the device from visiting a malicious website.
I prefer B,C

Selected Answer: BC
ESA and Umbrella should be the answer.

Selected Answer: BC
I would go for B and C, according to the links below:

https://trustportal.cisco.com/c/dam/r/ctp/docs/privacydatasheet/security/cisco-advanced-phishing-privacy-data-sheet.pdf

https://umbrella.cisco.com/trends-threats/how-to-stop-and-block-phishing-attacks

choices.A: using an inline IPS/IDS in the network

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
CI.. not CD

Selected Answer: C
CI, short for Continuous Integration, is a software development practice in which all developers merge code changes in a central repository multiple times daily. 

CD stands for Continuous Delivery, which on top of Continuous Integration, adds the practice of automating the entire software release process.

According to that, C is the right answer.

Selected Answer: C
CI as others have mentioned.

Selected Answer: C
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/data-center/data-center-networking/what-is-ci-cd.html#~ci-cd-explained

Continuous integration

In this first phase, developers merge their code changes with primary code repositories for their projects. As developers push out code, they automatically trigger software builds.

C. Continuous Integration (CI) is the process in DevSecOps where all changes in the central code repository are merged and synchronized. It is a development practice that requires developers to integrate code into a shared repository frequently. This allows teams to detect and fix conflicts early, and ensures that the code is always in a releasable state. The process of CI also includes automated builds and tests, which helps to catch any errors or issues before they are deployed to production.

Selected Answer: C
Definitely CI

Selected Answer: C
I prefer C:

Continuous integration (CI) allows multiple developers to contribute to a single shared repository. When code changes are merged, automated tests are run to ensure correctness before integration. Merging and testing code often help development teams gain reassurance in the quality and predictability of code once deployed.

Solution is C: CI

"Continuous integration (CI) is the process of automating and integrating code changes and updates from many team members during software development. In CI, automated tools confirm that software code is valid and error-free before it's integrated, which helps detect bugs and speed up new releases."

From:https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/data-center/data-center-networking/what-is-ci-cd.html#~ci-cd-explained

questions.question_text: What is the process in DevSecOps where all changes in the central code repository are merged and synchronized?
